_link.title: I can describe the flight path of a projectile and explain the effect of gravity on its trajectory

toLevel2.question: What shape does the flight path of a projectile follow when air resistance is ignored?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The combination of constant horizontal velocity and uniformly accelerated vertical motion produces a parabolic trajectory.

distractors.explanation: A straight line would require no acceleration; gravity curves the path into a parabola.
Circular motion requires a centripetal force; gravity acts only downward, producing a parabola.
Hyperbolic paths occur in certain orbital mechanics; near-Earth projectiles follow parabolas.

toLevel2.question: In which direction does gravity act on a projectile during its flight?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Gravity always acts vertically downward toward the centre of the Earth throughout the entire flight.

distractors.explanation: Gravity acts vertically downward, not along the curved trajectory of the projectile.
Gravity acts downward regardless of the projectile's direction of travel at any point.
Gravity has no horizontal component; it acts only in the vertical direction.

toLevel2.question: What happens to the horizontal velocity of a projectile during flight (ignoring air resistance)?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: With no horizontal force acting on the projectile, the horizontal velocity stays the same throughout the flight.

distractors.explanation: Without air resistance, no horizontal force acts to slow the projectile down.
No horizontal force means no horizontal acceleration, so the speed cannot increase.
Only the vertical velocity becomes zero at the peak; horizontal velocity is unchanged.

toLevel2.question: What is the vertical velocity of a projectile at the highest point of its trajectory?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: At the peak, the projectile has momentarily stopped moving upward and has not yet begun moving downward, so vertical velocity is zero.

distractors.explanation: The vertical component decreases as the projectile rises and reaches zero at the peak.
9.8 m/s squared is the acceleration due to gravity, not the velocity at the peak.
Vertical velocity is at its minimum (zero) at the peak, not its maximum.

toLevel2.question: What is the value of gravitational acceleration near the surface of Earth?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Near Earth's surface, all objects experience a gravitational acceleration of approximately 9.8 m/s squared directed downward.

distractors.explanation: The units of acceleration are metres per second squared, not metres per second.
Gravitational acceleration is directed downward toward Earth, not upward.
Gravitational acceleration is approximately 9.8 m/s squared at the surface, not zero.

toLevel2.question: A projectile follows a parabolic path because gravity acts only in the vertical direction.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Gravity provides a constant downward acceleration while horizontal motion is unaffected, producing the characteristic parabolic shape.

distractors.explanation: Students may think other forces shape the trajectory, but with air resistance ignored, only vertical gravity creates the parabola.

toLevel2.question: At the peak of its trajectory, a projectile has zero acceleration.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Gravity acts on the projectile throughout its flight, including at the peak. The acceleration is always 9.8 m/s squared downward, even when vertical velocity is momentarily zero.

distractors.explanation: Students often confuse zero vertical velocity at the peak with zero acceleration, but gravity continues to accelerate the projectile downward.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about projectile motion.
toLevel2.sentence: A projectile follows a {{blank:1}} path because gravity accelerates it {{blank:2}} throughout the flight.

1.correctExplanation: The combination of constant horizontal motion and accelerated vertical motion traces out a parabola.

distractors.explanation: Circular paths require centripetal force; projectiles near Earth follow parabolas.
A straight line would require no net force; gravity curves the path.

2.correctExplanation: Gravity always acts vertically downward, which is the only acceleration on the projectile.

distractors.explanation: Gravity has no component along the horizontal direction of travel.
Gravity does not oppose the horizontal motion; it acts vertically downward.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about velocity components.
toLevel2.sentence: During projectile flight, the {{blank:1}} velocity remains constant while the {{blank:2}} velocity changes due to gravity.

1.correctExplanation: No horizontal force acts on the projectile (ignoring air resistance), so horizontal velocity is constant.

distractors.explanation: Vertical velocity changes continuously because gravity accelerates the projectile downward.
The total speed changes as the vertical component changes; only horizontal stays constant.

2.correctExplanation: Gravity accelerates the projectile downward at 9.8 m/s squared, continuously changing the vertical velocity.

distractors.explanation: Horizontal velocity stays constant because no horizontal force acts on the projectile.
Angular velocity is not a standard component in projectile motion analysis.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about the peak of a trajectory.
toLevel2.sentence: At the highest point, a projectile's vertical velocity is {{blank:1}} but gravity still provides an acceleration of {{blank:2}} m/s squared downward.

1.correctExplanation: The vertical velocity decreases to zero at the peak before the projectile begins falling back down.

distractors.explanation: Vertical velocity is at its minimum (zero) at the peak, not maximum.
At the exact peak, vertical velocity is zero; it becomes negative only after the peak.

2.correctExplanation: Gravitational acceleration remains constant at 9.8 m/s squared throughout the entire flight, including at the peak.

distractors.explanation: Acceleration due to gravity does not become zero at the peak; only vertical velocity is zero.
4.9 is half of 9.8 and appears in displacement equations, but the acceleration is always 9.8 m/s squared.

toLevel3.question: Why does a projectile's path curve downward rather than continue in a straight line after launch?
toLevel3.correct: Gravity continuously accelerates the projectile downward
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The constant downward pull of gravity adds an increasing downward displacement over time, bending the path into a curve.

distractors.answer: The projectile runs out of forward momentum
distractors.explanation: Horizontal momentum is conserved; the curve is caused by gravity, not loss of forward motion.

distractors.answer: Air resistance pushes the projectile downward
distractors.explanation: Air resistance opposes motion but does not cause the fundamental parabolic curve; gravity does.

distractors.answer: The launch force wears off during the flight
distractors.explanation: Once launched, no launch force acts on the projectile; gravity alone curves the path.

toLevel3.question: Why is the vertical velocity zero at the peak of a projectile's trajectory, yet the projectile does not remain stationary there?
toLevel3.correct: Gravity continues to accelerate it downward from that point
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Although vertical velocity is momentarily zero, the constant downward acceleration immediately begins increasing the downward velocity.

distractors.answer: Horizontal velocity pushes the projectile past peak
distractors.explanation: Horizontal motion continues but does not explain why the projectile descends; gravity causes the descent.

distractors.answer: The projectile stores energy that releases at peak
distractors.explanation: No energy is stored and released; gravity acts continuously.

distractors.answer: Air pressure forces the projectile back downward
distractors.explanation: Air pressure does not push projectiles down; gravitational acceleration is responsible.

toLevel3.question: How does the trajectory of a projectile launched horizontally differ from one launched at an angle above horizontal?
toLevel3.correct: The horizontal launch has no initial upward motion so it descends immediately
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A horizontal launch starts with zero vertical velocity, so the projectile begins falling right away rather than rising first.

distractors.answer: The horizontal launch follows a straight diagonal line
distractors.explanation: Both trajectories are parabolic; the horizontal launch just begins curving downward from the start.

distractors.answer: The angled launch has no horizontal velocity at all
distractors.explanation: An angled launch has both horizontal and vertical components of velocity.

distractors.answer: The horizontal launch is not affected by gravity
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts on all projectiles regardless of their launch angle.

toLevel3.question: What does it mean to say the horizontal and vertical motions of a projectile are independent?
toLevel3.correct: Each component can be analysed separately without affecting the other
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Gravity affects only the vertical motion, and horizontal motion proceeds unchanged, so the two can be treated independently.

distractors.answer: The projectile can only move in one direction at once
distractors.explanation: A projectile moves in both directions simultaneously; independence means the components don't influence each other.

distractors.answer: Horizontal motion stops when vertical motion starts
distractors.explanation: Both motions occur simultaneously throughout the flight.

distractors.answer: Vertical motion has no effect on the overall path
distractors.explanation: Vertical motion absolutely affects the path; independence means the two components don't affect each other.

toLevel3.question: A ball is kicked at an angle. Why is the descending half of its trajectory a mirror image of the ascending half (ignoring air resistance)?
toLevel3.correct: Gravitational acceleration is constant and symmetric about the peak
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Constant downward acceleration produces equal changes in vertical velocity going up and coming down, creating a symmetric path.

distractors.answer: The ball speeds up equally in both directions
distractors.explanation: The total speed is not equal at every symmetric pair of points; horizontal is constant but vertical reverses.

distractors.answer: The ball has the same height at launch and landing
distractors.explanation: Equal heights at start and end are a result of symmetry, not its cause.

distractors.answer: Wind pushes equally on both halves of the path
distractors.explanation: Symmetry arises from constant gravitational acceleration, not wind effects.

toLevel3.question: Why does a water jet from a hose follow a curved path rather than a straight one?
toLevel3.correct: Gravity pulls the water downward while it moves forward
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The water has constant horizontal velocity from the hose, but gravity accelerates it downward, creating a parabolic arc.

distractors.answer: Water pressure decreases as the jet travels further
distractors.explanation: Once the water leaves the hose, pressure is no longer relevant; gravity shapes the curve.

distractors.answer: The water molecules slow down due to cohesion forces
distractors.explanation: Cohesion does not cause the curved trajectory; gravity is responsible.

distractors.answer: Air resistance bends the water jet downward
distractors.explanation: While air resistance has some effect, the primary cause of the curve is gravitational acceleration.

toLevel3.question: A projectile launched at an angle has the same horizontal velocity at the start and end of its flight (ignoring air resistance).
toLevel3.correctExplanation: With no horizontal force, the horizontal component of velocity remains constant throughout the entire trajectory.

distractors.explanation: Students may think the projectile slows down overall, but the horizontal component specifically remains unchanged when air resistance is ignored.

toLevel3.prompt: Explain why a projectile follows a parabolic path.
toLevel3.sentence: A parabolic trajectory results from combining {{blank:1}} horizontal motion with uniformly {{blank:2}} vertical motion.

1.correctExplanation: Horizontal velocity does not change because no horizontal force acts on the projectile.

distractors.explanation: There is no horizontal force, so horizontal motion is constant, not accelerating.
Without air resistance, no force acts to slow horizontal motion.

2.correctExplanation: Gravity provides a constant downward acceleration of 9.8 m/s squared, uniformly changing the vertical velocity.

distractors.explanation: Vertical velocity changes continuously due to gravitational acceleration.
Vertical velocity changes steadily in one direction, not back and forth.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the explanation of trajectory symmetry.
toLevel3.sentence: The ascending and descending halves of a projectile's path are symmetric because gravitational {{blank:1}} is constant and the vertical velocity at any height is equal in {{blank:2}} on each side of the peak.

1.correctExplanation: The constant value of gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s squared downward) ensures the trajectory is symmetric.

distractors.explanation: Gravitational velocity is not a standard term; the constant quantity is gravitational acceleration.
While gravitational force is constant for a given mass, the key physics concept here is constant acceleration.

2.correctExplanation: At the same height, the vertical speed is the same going up as going down, just in opposite directions.

distractors.explanation: The directions are opposite on each side; it is the magnitude (size) that is equal.
Duration describes time, not the equality of speed values at matching heights.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the comparison of launch conditions.
toLevel3.sentence: A projectile launched horizontally from a cliff begins with zero {{blank:1}} velocity, so it starts falling {{blank:2}} from the moment of release.

1.correctExplanation: A horizontal launch means all initial velocity is horizontal; vertical velocity starts at zero.

distractors.explanation: A horizontal launch has nonzero horizontal velocity; it is the vertical component that starts at zero.
The total initial speed is not zero for a horizontal launch; only the vertical component is zero.

2.correctExplanation: With no initial upward velocity, gravity begins pulling the projectile downward from the instant of release.

distractors.explanation: The projectile begins falling at the instant of release, not after a delay.
There is no delay; gravity acts from the very first moment of flight.

toLevel4.question: A ball is thrown horizontally at 15 m/s from the edge of a 20 m high cliff. How far from the base of the cliff does it land? (Use g = 9.8 m/s squared.)
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Time to fall 20 m: t = sqrt(2 x 20 / 9.8) = 2.02 s. Horizontal distance = 15 x 2.02 = 30.3 m, approximately 30 m.

distractors.explanation: This uses only the horizontal speed without correctly calculating the fall time from the height.
This overestimates the fall time or incorrectly doubles the horizontal distance.
This confuses the vertical drop distance with the horizontal range.

toLevel4.question: A projectile is launched at 40 m/s at 30 degrees above horizontal. What is the initial vertical component of the velocity?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The vertical component = 40 x sin(30 degrees) = 40 x 0.5 = 20 m/s upward.

distractors.explanation: This is the horizontal component (40 x cos 30), not the vertical component.
40 m/s is the total launch speed, not the vertical component alone.
This incorrectly halves the vertical component or uses the wrong trigonometric function.

toLevel4.question: A football is kicked at an angle. At the highest point of its trajectory, which statement about its velocity is correct?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At the peak, the vertical velocity is zero but the horizontal velocity remains unchanged, so only horizontal velocity exists.

distractors.explanation: Only vertical velocity is zero at the peak; horizontal velocity remains constant throughout.
Vertical velocity is zero at the peak; the projectile retains its horizontal velocity.
At the peak, the speed equals only the horizontal component, which is less than the full launch speed.

toLevel4.question: Two balls are released from the same height at the same instant: one is dropped vertically and the other is thrown horizontally. Which hits the ground first?
toLevel4.correct: They hit the ground at the same time
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Both have the same initial vertical velocity (zero) and the same vertical acceleration (g), so they fall the same vertical distance in the same time.

distractors.explanation: The horizontal velocity of the thrown ball does not affect its vertical fall time.
Horizontal motion does not change the time taken to fall a given vertical distance.
Vertical and horizontal motions are independent; horizontal speed does not influence fall time.

toLevel4.question: A projectile is launched at 25 m/s at 60 degrees above horizontal. What is its speed at the highest point of the trajectory?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: At the peak, only horizontal velocity remains: v_x = 25 x cos(60) = 25 x 0.5 = 12.5 m/s.

distractors.explanation: Only the vertical component is zero at the peak; the horizontal component of 12.5 m/s persists.
25 m/s is the launch speed; at the peak, speed equals just the horizontal component.
This is the initial vertical component (25 x sin 60), not the speed at the peak.

toLevel4.question: A stone is thrown horizontally from a bridge and takes 3.0 s to reach the water below. What is the vertical velocity just before it hits the water?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Vertical velocity = g x t = 9.8 x 3.0 = 29.4 m/s downward, since initial vertical velocity is zero.

distractors.explanation: 9.8 m/s squared is the acceleration, not the final velocity after 3 seconds of falling.
44.1 m is the vertical distance fallen (0.5 x 9.8 x 9), not the velocity.
This uses half the correct time or incorrectly divides; v = 9.8 x 3.0 = 29.4 m/s.

toLevel4.question: A cannonball is fired at 50 m/s at 45 degrees. What is the maximum height reached? (Use g = 9.8 m/s squared.)
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Vertical component = 50 x sin(45) = 35.36 m/s. Maximum height = v_y squared / (2g) = 35.36 squared / (2 x 9.8) = 1250 / 19.6 = 63.8 m.

distractors.explanation: This incorrectly uses the full launch speed instead of just the vertical component.
This halves the correct answer, perhaps using an incorrect formula.
This results from a calculation error, not the correct application of v squared = 2gh.

toLevel4.prompt: Apply projectile motion equations to this scenario.
toLevel4.sentence: A ball thrown horizontally at 10 m/s from a 44.1 m high building takes {{blank:1}} seconds to reach the ground, landing {{blank:2}} m from the base of the building.

1.correctExplanation: Using h = 0.5 x g x t squared: 44.1 = 0.5 x 9.8 x t squared, so t squared = 9.0, giving t = 3.0 s.

distractors.explanation: This incorrectly uses h = g x t instead of h = 0.5 x g x t squared.
This results from a calculation error in solving the displacement equation.

2.correctExplanation: Horizontal distance = horizontal speed x time = 10 x 3.0 = 30 m.

distractors.explanation: 44.1 m is the vertical height, not the horizontal distance.
10 m/s is the horizontal speed, not the horizontal distance.

toLevel4.prompt: Determine the velocity components for this projectile.
toLevel4.sentence: A projectile launched at 30 m/s at 60 degrees has an initial horizontal velocity of {{blank:1}} m/s and an initial vertical velocity of {{blank:2}} m/s.

1.correctExplanation: Horizontal component = 30 x cos(60) = 30 x 0.5 = 15 m/s.

distractors.explanation: 26 m/s is the vertical component (30 x sin 60), not the horizontal component.
30 m/s is the total speed; the horizontal component requires multiplying by cos(60).

2.correctExplanation: Vertical component = 30 x sin(60) = 30 x 0.866 = 26.0 m/s (rounded).

distractors.explanation: 15 m/s is the horizontal component (30 x cos 60), not the vertical component.
30 m/s is the total speed; the vertical component requires multiplying by sin(60).

toLevel4.prompt: Calculate the fall time for this projectile.
toLevel4.sentence: A stone dropped from rest takes {{blank:1}} seconds to fall 19.6 m, reaching a final vertical speed of {{blank:2}} m/s.

1.correctExplanation: Using h = 0.5 x g x t squared: 19.6 = 0.5 x 9.8 x t squared, so t squared = 4.0, giving t = 2.0 s.

distractors.explanation: In 1.0 s the stone falls only 4.9 m, not 19.6 m.
In 4.0 s the stone would fall 78.4 m, much further than 19.6 m.

2.correctExplanation: Final speed = g x t = 9.8 x 2.0 = 19.6 m/s.

distractors.explanation: 9.8 m/s is the speed after 1.0 s, not after 2.0 s.
This doubles the correct value, as if using t = 4.0 s.

toLevel5.question: A student claims that a projectile is in equilibrium at the peak of its trajectory because its vertical velocity is zero. Evaluate this claim.
toLevel5.correct: Incorrect: a net downward gravitational force still acts, so it is not in equilibrium
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Equilibrium requires zero net force. Gravity acts on the projectile at all times, including at the peak where the vertical velocity is momentarily zero.

distractors.answer: Correct: zero vertical velocity means zero net force
distractors.explanation: Zero velocity does not mean zero force; gravity provides a constant unbalanced force downward.

distractors.answer: Correct: the projectile is momentarily stationary at peak
distractors.explanation: The projectile still has horizontal velocity at the peak and an unbalanced gravitational force.

distractors.answer: Incorrect: but only because horizontal velocity exists
distractors.explanation: Equilibrium depends on net force being zero, not velocity; the key issue is that gravity still acts.

toLevel5.question: Compare two projectiles launched at the same speed: one at 30 degrees and one at 60 degrees above horizontal. What can be concluded about their ranges on flat ground?
toLevel5.correct: They have equal ranges because complementary angles produce the same range
toLevel5.correctExplanation: For the same launch speed on level ground, angles that sum to 90 degrees produce identical horizontal ranges because sin(2 x 30) = sin(2 x 60).

distractors.explanation: While 30 degrees has greater horizontal velocity, 60 degrees has longer flight time; the ranges are equal.
While 60 degrees reaches higher altitude, 30 degrees covers more ground per second; the ranges are equal.

distractors.answer: Range depends only on launch speed, not angle
distractors.explanation: Range depends on both speed and angle; complementary angles happen to give equal range.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why real projectiles such as golf balls deviate from the ideal parabolic path. Which factor is most significant?
toLevel5.correct: Air resistance reduces horizontal velocity and changes the trajectory shape
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Air resistance provides a force opposing motion, reducing horizontal velocity over time and making the descent steeper than the ascent.

distractors.answer: Gravity increases during the flight of the projectile
distractors.explanation: Gravitational acceleration is effectively constant over the distances a golf ball travels.

distractors.answer: The ball's mass decreases as it travels through air
distractors.explanation: A golf ball's mass does not change during flight.

distractors.answer: Earth's rotation deflects the ball during its flight
distractors.explanation: While the Coriolis effect exists, it is negligible for golf ball distances compared to air resistance.

toLevel5.question: A physics experiment drops Ball A from rest and simultaneously fires Ball B horizontally from the same height. Both hit the ground at the same time. What does this demonstrate about the independence of motion components?
toLevel5.correct: Horizontal motion does not influence the rate of vertical fall
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Since both balls fall the same vertical distance in the same time, horizontal velocity has no effect on vertical acceleration.

distractors.answer: The horizontal ball experiences a greater gravitational force
distractors.explanation: Both balls have the same gravitational acceleration regardless of horizontal motion.

distractors.answer: Gravity only acts on objects that are stationary horizontally
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts equally on all objects regardless of their horizontal velocity.

distractors.answer: The experiment would not work outside a vacuum chamber
distractors.explanation: The result is visible in air; air resistance slightly affects timing but the principle holds.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that since a projectile decelerates on the way up and accelerates on the way down, there must be two different forces acting. Critique this reasoning.
toLevel5.correct: Only one force acts: gravity decelerates upward motion and accelerates downward motion
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Gravity is the sole force throughout. It opposes upward velocity (deceleration) and enhances downward velocity (acceleration), but it is the same constant force.

distractors.answer: The student is correct that two forces are required
distractors.explanation: A single constant downward force explains both the deceleration up and acceleration down.

distractors.answer: There are zero forces at the peak between the two phases
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts continuously, including at the peak; there is no force-free moment.

distractors.answer: A third force at the peak switches between the two
distractors.explanation: No switching mechanism exists; gravity is one constant downward force throughout.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate: For maximum horizontal range on level ground, a launch angle of 45 degrees is optimal. Why does this angle provide the best balance?
toLevel5.correct: It maximises the product of horizontal velocity and flight time
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Range = horizontal velocity x flight time. At 45 degrees, the product of cos(theta) and sin(theta) is maximised, giving the greatest range.

distractors.answer: It minimises the effect of gravity on the projectile
distractors.explanation: Gravitational acceleration is the same regardless of launch angle; 45 degrees optimises the velocity split.

distractors.answer: It produces the longest possible flight time overall
distractors.explanation: A 90-degree launch gives the longest flight time; 45 degrees balances time and horizontal speed.

distractors.answer: It gives the highest horizontal velocity component
distractors.explanation: A 0-degree launch gives maximum horizontal velocity; 45 degrees balances both components.

toLevel5.question: Data from a projectile experiment shows the landing point is significantly short of the predicted range. Assuming the launch speed and angle were correct, which explanation is most likely?
toLevel5.correct: Air resistance reduced the horizontal velocity during flight
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Air resistance acts opposite to motion, slowing horizontal velocity and reducing the actual range below the theoretical prediction.

distractors.answer: Gravity was stronger than 9.8 m/s squared that day
distractors.explanation: Gravitational acceleration does not vary significantly at a given location from day to day.

distractors.answer: The projectile gained mass during its flight path
distractors.explanation: Projectile mass does not increase during flight; air resistance is the primary cause.

distractors.answer: The launch angle was secretly more than 45 degrees
distractors.explanation: The problem states the angle was correct; the shortfall is due to air resistance.

toLevel5.question: Compare the acceleration vectors of a projectile at three points: just after launch, at the peak, and just before landing. What pattern emerges?
toLevel5.correct: All three acceleration vectors are identical in magnitude and direction
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Gravitational acceleration is constant at 9.8 m/s squared downward at every point in the trajectory, regardless of position or velocity.

distractors.answer: Acceleration is upward after launch, zero at peak, and downward before landing
distractors.explanation: Acceleration is always 9.8 m/s squared downward; it never points upward or becomes zero.

distractors.answer: Acceleration increases as the projectile descends
distractors.explanation: Gravitational acceleration remains constant at 9.8 m/s squared regardless of height changes over these distances.

distractors.answer: Acceleration is largest at the peak where velocity is lowest
distractors.explanation: Acceleration does not depend on velocity; it is constant at 9.8 m/s squared downward throughout.

toLevel5.prompt: Analyse the relationship between launch angle and range.
toLevel5.sentence: Maximum range on flat ground occurs at {{blank:1}} degrees because this angle maximises the product of {{blank:2}} velocity and flight time.

1.correctExplanation: At 45 degrees, sin(2 x 45) = sin(90) = 1, which maximises the range formula R = v squared x sin(2 theta) / g.

distractors.explanation: 60 degrees gives a longer flight time but lower horizontal velocity, resulting in less range than 45 degrees.
30 degrees gives greater horizontal velocity but shorter flight time, resulting in less range than 45 degrees.

2.correctExplanation: Range equals horizontal velocity multiplied by total flight time; 45 degrees optimises this product.

distractors.explanation: Vertical velocity determines height and flight time, but range depends on horizontal velocity times time.
Terminal velocity is related to air resistance, not the range optimisation of projectile motion.

toLevel5.prompt: Evaluate the effect of air resistance on projectile motion.
toLevel5.sentence: Air resistance makes a real projectile's trajectory {{blank:1}} compared to the ideal parabola, because the {{blank:2}} half of the path is steeper than the ascending half.

1.correctExplanation: Air resistance reduces horizontal velocity over time, making the descending path steeper and the trajectory no longer a perfect parabola.

distractors.explanation: Air resistance breaks the symmetry by reducing speed throughout the flight, especially in the horizontal direction.
Air resistance does not produce a circular path; it creates an asymmetric curve steeper on descent.

2.correctExplanation: By the descending phase, air resistance has reduced horizontal velocity, so the projectile drops more steeply.

distractors.explanation: The ascending half is less affected; cumulative velocity loss makes the descending half steeper.
The horizontal portion is not a distinct phase; the trajectory becomes steeper on the way down.
